text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
CodeSystem NDomainResourceDeclares the existence of and describes a code system or code system supplement
+ Warning: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation
+ Rule: Within a code system definition, all the codes SHALL be unique
+ Warning: If there is a explicit hierarchy, a hierarchyMeaning should be provided
+ Warning: If there is a implicit hierarchy, a hierarchyMeaning should be provided
+ Rule: If the code system content = supplement, it must nominate what it's a supplement for

Elements defined in Ancestors: id, meta, implicitRules, language, text, contained, extension, modifierExtension
Interfaces Implemented: MetadataResource
url ΣC0..1uriCanonical identifier for this code system, represented as a URI (globally unique) (Coding.system)
+ Warning: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic
identifier Σ0..*IdentifierAdditional identifier for the code system (business identifier)

version Σ0..1stringBusiness version of the code system (Coding.version)
name ΣC0..1stringName for this code system (computer friendly)
title ΣT0..1stringName for this code system (human friendly)
status ?!Σ1..1codedraft | active | retired | unknown
PublicationStatus (Required)
experimental Σ0..1booleanFor testing purposes, not real usage
date Σ0..1dateTimeDate last changed
publisher ΣT0..1stringName of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
contact Σ0..*ContactDetailContact details for the publisher

description T0..1markdownNatural language description of the code system
useContext ΣTU0..*UsageContextThe context that the content is intended to support

jurisdiction Σ0..*CodeableConceptIntended jurisdiction for code system (if applicable)
Jurisdiction ValueSet (Extensible)

purpose T0..1markdownWhy this code system is defined
copyright T0..1markdownUse and/or publishing restrictions
approvalDate TU0..1dateWhen the CodeSystem was approved by publisher
lastReviewDate TU0..1dateWhen the CodeSystem was last reviewed
effectivePeriod ΣTU0..1PeriodWhen the CodeSystem is expected to be used
topic TU0..*CodeableConceptE.g. Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc.
DefinitionTopic (Example)

author TU0..*ContactDetailWho authored the CodeSystem

editor TU0..*ContactDetailWho edited the CodeSystem

reviewer TU0..*ContactDetailWho reviewed the CodeSystem

endorser TU0..*ContactDetailWho endorsed the CodeSystem

relatedArtifact TU0..*RelatedArtifactAdditional documentation, citations, etc.

caseSensitive Σ0..1booleanIf code comparison is case sensitive
valueSet Σ0..1canonical(ValueSet)Canonical reference to the value set with entire code system
hierarchyMeaning Σ0..1codegrouped-by | is-a | part-of | classified-with
CodeSystemHierarchyMeaning (Required)
compositional Σ0..1booleanIf code system defines a compositional grammar
versionNeeded Σ0..1booleanIf definitions are not stable
content Σ1..1codenot-present | example | fragment | complete | supplement
CodeSystemContentMode (Required)
supplements ΣTU0..1canonical(CodeSystem)Canonical URL of Code System this adds designations and properties to
count Σ0..1unsignedIntTotal concepts in the code system
filter Σ0..*BackboneElementFilter that can be used in a value set

code Σ1..1codeCode that identifies the filter
description Σ0..1stringHow or why the filter is used
operator Σ1..*code= | is-a | descendent-of | is-not-a | regex | in | not-in | generalizes | child-of | descendent-leaf | exists
FilterOperator (Required)

value Σ1..1stringWhat to use for the value
property Σ0..*BackboneElementAdditional information supplied about each concept

code Σ1..1codeIdentifies the property on the concepts, and when referred to in operations
uri Σ0..1uriFormal identifier for the property
description Σ0..1stringWhy the property is defined, and/or what it conveys
type Σ1..1codecode | Coding | string | integer | boolean | dateTime | decimal
PropertyType (Required)
concept 0..*BackboneElementConcepts in the code system

code 1..1codeCode that identifies concept
display 0..1stringText to display to the user
definition 0..1stringFormal definition
designation C0..*BackboneElementAdditional representations for the concept
+ Rule: Must have a value for concept.designation.use if concept.designation.additionalUse is present

language 0..1codeHuman language of the designation
Common Languages (Preferred but limited to AllLanguages)
use 0..1CodingDetails how this designation would be used
Designation Use (Extensible)
additionalUse 0..*CodingAdditional ways how this designation would be used
Designation Use (Extensible)

value 1..1stringThe text value for this designation
property 0..*BackboneElementProperty value for the concept

code 1..1codeReference to CodeSystem.property.code
value[x] 1..1Value of the property for this concept
valueCodecode
valueCodingCoding
valueStringstring
valueIntegerinteger
valueBooleanboolean
valueDateTimedateTime
valueDecimaldecimal
concept 0..*see conceptChild Concepts (is-a/contains/categorizes)


Documentation for this format

name: CodeSystem
description: The CodeSystem resource is used to declare the existence of and describe a code system or code system supplement and its key properties, and optionally define a part or all of its content.

element.short: Declares the existence of and describes a code system or code system supplement
element.definition: The CodeSystem resource is used to declare the existence of and describe a code system or code system supplement and its key properties, and optionally define a part or all of its content.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation
Within a code system definition, all the codes SHALL be unique
If there is a explicit hierarchy, a hierarchyMeaning should be provided
If there is a implicit hierarchy, a hierarchyMeaning should be provided
If the code system content = supplement, it must nominate what it's a supplement for

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: Within the context of the FHIR RESTful interactions, the resource has an id except for cases like the create and conditional update. Otherwise, the use of the resouce id depends on the given use case.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have a narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, nor can they have their own independent transaction scope. This is allowed to be a Parameters resource if and only if it is referenced by a resource that provides context/meaning.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags in their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: Canonical identifier for this code system, represented as a URI (globally unique) (Coding.system)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this code system when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this code system is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the code system is stored on different servers. This is used in [Coding](datatypes.html#Coding).system.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the code system to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional identifier for the code system (business identifier)
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this code system when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this code system outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.  Note that HL7 defines at least three identifiers for many of its code systems - the FHIR canonical URL, the OID and the V2 Table 0396 mnemonic code.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Business version of the code system (Coding.version)
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the code system when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the code system author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence. This is used in [Coding](datatypes.html#Coding).version.
element.comment: There may be different code system instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the code system with the format [url]|[version]. The version SHOULD NOT contain a '#' - see [Business Version](resource.html#bv-format).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this code system (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the code system. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this code system (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the code system.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: draft | active | retired | unknown
element.definition: The status of this code system. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of code systems that are appropriate for use versus not.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired CodeSystem without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this code system is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of code systems that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level code system.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Date last changed
element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the code system was last significantly changed. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the code system changes.
element.comment: The date is often not tracked until the resource is published, but may be present on draft content. Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the code system. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the code system.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the code system is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the code system. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the code system. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the code system.  May also allow for contact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contact details for the publisher
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Natural language description of the code system
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the code system from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the code system as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the code system is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the code system was created).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate code system instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for code system (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the code system is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the code system to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.short: Why this code system is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this code system is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the code system. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this code system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Use and/or publishing restrictions
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the code system and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the code system.
element.comment: ... Sometimes, the copyright differs between the code system and the codes that are included. The copyright statement should clearly differentiate between these when required.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the code system and/or its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the CodeSystem was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the CodeSystem was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the CodeSystem is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the CodeSystem content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.comment: The effective period for a CodeSystem  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the CodeSystem are or are expected to be used instead.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: E.g. Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc.
element.definition: Descriptions related to the content of the CodeSystem. Topics provide a high-level categorization as well as keywords for the CodeSystem that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.comment: This element provides topical categorization and keywords for the CodeSystem, as opposed to the more structured context-of-use information provided in the useContext element
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the CodeSystem so that it can be found by topical and keyword searches.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who authored the CodeSystem
element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the CodeSystem.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who edited the CodeSystem
element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the CodeSystem.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who reviewed the CodeSystem
element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the CodeSystem.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Who endorsed the CodeSystem
element.definition: An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the CodeSystem for use in some setting.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional documentation, citations, etc.
element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, dependencies, bibliographic references, and predecessor and successor artifacts.
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.
element.requirements: A CodeSystem must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: If code comparison is case sensitive
element.definition: If code comparison is case sensitive when codes within this system are compared to each other.
element.comment: If this value is missing, then it is not specified whether a code system is case sensitive or not. When the rule is not known, Postel's law should be followed: produce codes with the correct case, and accept codes in any case. This element is primarily provided to support validation software.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Canonical reference to the value set with entire code system
element.definition: Canonical reference to the value set that contains all codes in the code system independent of code status.
element.comment: The definition of the value set SHALL include all codes from this code system, independent of concept status, and only codes from this code system. It SHALL be immutable, and operations SHOULD support validation of any allowed code compositions.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: grouped-by | is-a | part-of | classified-with
element.definition: The meaning of the hierarchy of concepts as represented in this resource.
element.comment: Note that other representations might have a different hierarchy or none at all, and represent the information using properties.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The meaning of the hierarchy of concepts in a code system.

element.short: If code system defines a compositional grammar
element.definition: The code system defines a compositional (post-coordination) grammar.
element.comment: Note that the code system resource does not define what the compositional grammar is, only whether or not there is one.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: If definitions are not stable
element.definition: This flag is used to signify that the code system does not commit to concept permanence across versions. If true, a version must be specified when referencing this code system.
element.comment:
Best practice is that code systems do not redefine concepts, or that if concepts are redefined, a new code system definition is created. But this is not always possible, so some code systems may be defined as 'versionNeeded'.

Most code systems occasionally refine the displays defined for concepts between versions. Contexts in which the concept display values are validated may require that the version be specified for some code systems irrespective of the value of this property.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: not-present | example | fragment | complete | supplement
element.definition: The extent of the content of the code system (the concepts and codes it defines) are represented in this resource instance.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The extent of the content of the code system (the concepts and codes it defines) are represented in a code system resource.

element.short: Canonical URL of Code System this adds designations and properties to
element.definition: The canonical URL of the code system that this code system supplement is adding designations and properties to.
element.comment: The most common use of a code system supplement is to add additional language support.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Total concepts in the code system
element.definition: The total number of concepts defined by the code system. Where the code system has a compositional grammar, the basis of this count is defined by the system steward.
element.comment: The count of concepts defined in this resource cannot be more than this value but may be less for several reasons - see the content element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Filter that can be used in a value set
element.definition: A filter that can be used in a value set compose statement when selecting concepts using a filter.
element.comment: Note that filters defined in code systems usually require custom code on the part of any terminology engine that will make them available for use in value set filters. For this reason, they are generally only seen in high value published terminologies.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Code that identifies the filter
element.definition: The code that identifies this filter when it is used as a filter in [ValueSet](valueset.html#).compose.include.filter.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: How or why the filter is used
element.definition: A description of how or why the filter is used.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: = | is-a | descendent-of | is-not-a | regex | in | not-in | generalizes | child-of | descendent-leaf | exists
element.definition: A list of operators that can be used with the filter.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The kind of operation to perform as a part of a property based filter.

element.short: What to use for the value
element.definition: A description of what the value for the filter should be.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional information supplied about each concept
element.definition: A property defines an additional slot through which additional information can be provided about a concept.
element.comment: Multiple occurrences of CodeSystem.concept.property may occur for a CodeSystem.property where     CodeSystem.concept.property.code is the same and CodeSystem.concept.property.value differs. For example: multiple designations for a single concept.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Identifies the property on the concepts, and when referred to in operations
element.definition: A code that is used to identify the property. The code is used internally (in CodeSystem.concept.property.code) and also externally, such as in property filters.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Formal identifier for the property
element.definition: Reference to the formal meaning of the property. One possible source of meaning is the [Concept Properties](codesystem-concept-properties.html) code system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Why the property is defined, and/or what it conveys
element.definition: A description of the property- why it is defined, and how its value might be used.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: code | Coding | string | integer | boolean | dateTime | decimal
element.definition: The type of the property value. Properties of type "code" contain a code defined by the code system (e.g. a reference to another defined concept).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of a property value.

element.short: Concepts in the code system
element.definition: Concepts that are in the code system. The concept definitions are inherently hierarchical, but the definitions must be consulted to determine what the meanings of the hierarchical relationships are.
element.comment: If this is empty, it means that the code system resource does not represent the content of the code system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Code that identifies concept
element.definition: A code - a text symbol - that uniquely identifies the concept within the code system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text to display to the user
element.definition: A human readable string that is the recommended default way to present this concept to a user.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Formal definition
element.definition: The formal definition of the concept. The code system resource does not make formal definitions required, because of the prevalence of legacy systems. However, they are highly recommended, as without them there is no formal meaning associated with the concept.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional representations for the concept
element.definition: Additional representations for the concept - other languages, aliases, specialized purposes, used for particular purposes, etc.
element.comment: Concepts have both a ```display``` and an array of ```designation```. The display is equivalent to a special designation with an implied ```designation.use``` of "primary code" and a language equal to the [Resource Language](resource.html#language).
element.requirements: Many concept definition systems support multiple representations, in multiple languages, and for multiple purposes.

constraint.human: Must have a value for concept.designation.use if concept.designation.additionalUse is present
All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Human language of the designation
element.definition: The language this designation is defined for.
element.comment: In the absence of a language, the resource language applies.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Details how this designation would be used
element.definition: A code that details how this designation would be used.
element.comment: If no use is provided, the designation can be assumed to be suitable for general display to a human user.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Details of how a designation would be used.

element.short: Additional ways how this designation would be used
element.definition: Additional codes that detail how this designation would be used, if there is more than one use.
element.comment: This was added rather than increasing the cardinality of .use to 0..* in order to maintain backward compatibility.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Details of how a designation would be used.

element.short: The text value for this designation
element.definition: The text value for this designation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Property value for the concept
element.definition: A property value for this concept.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Reference to CodeSystem.property.code
element.definition: A code that is a reference to CodeSystem.property.code.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Value of the property for this concept
element.definition: The value of this property.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Child Concepts (is-a/contains/categorizes)
element.definition: Defines children of a concept to produce a hierarchy of concepts. The nature of the relationships is variable (is-a/contains/categorizes) - see hierarchyMeaning.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Declares the existence of and describes a code system or code system supplement
element.definition: The CodeSystem resource is used to declare the existence of and describe a code system or code system supplement and its key properties, and optionally define a part or all of its content.

constraint.human: Within a code system definition, all the codes SHALL be unique
If there is a explicit hierarchy, a hierarchyMeaning should be provided
If there is a implicit hierarchy, a hierarchyMeaning should be provided
Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation
If the code system content = supplement, it must nominate what it's a supplement for

element.short: Canonical identifier for this code system, represented as a URI (globally unique) (Coding.system)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this code system when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which an authoritative instance of this code system is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the code system is stored on different servers. This is used in [Coding](datatypes.html#Coding).system.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the code system to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: URL should not contain | or # - these characters make processing canonical references problematic

element.short: Additional identifier for the code system (business identifier)
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this code system when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this code system outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.  Note that HL7 defines at least three identifiers for many of its code systems - the FHIR canonical URL, the OID and the V2 Table 0396 mnemonic code.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

element.short: Business version of the code system (Coding.version)
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the code system when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the code system author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence. This is used in [Coding](datatypes.html#Coding).version.
element.comment: There may be different code system instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the code system with the format [url]|[version]. The version SHOULD NOT contain a '#' - see [Business Version](resource.html#bv-format).

element.short: Name for this code system (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the code system. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

element.short: Name for this code system (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the code system.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.short: draft | active | retired | unknown
element.definition: The status of this code system. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of code systems that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired CodeSystem without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this code system is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of code systems that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level code system.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If absent, this resource is treated as though it is not experimental.

element.short: Date last changed
element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the code system was last significantly changed. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the code system changes.
element.comment: The date is often not tracked until the resource is published, but may be present on draft content. Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the code system. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.short: Name of the publisher/steward (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual responsible for the release and ongoing maintenance of the code system.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the code system is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the code system. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the code system. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the code system.  May also allow for contact.

element.short: Contact details for the publisher
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.short: Natural language description of the code system
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the code system from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the code system as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the code system is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the code system was created).

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate code system instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

element.short: Intended jurisdiction for code system (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the code system is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the code system to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.short: Why this code system is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this code system is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the code system. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this code system.

element.short: Use and/or publishing restrictions
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the code system and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the code system.
element.comment: ... Sometimes, the copyright differs between the code system and the codes that are included. The copyright statement should clearly differentiate between these when required.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the code system and/or its content.

element.short: When the CodeSystem was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

element.short: When the CodeSystem was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

element.short: When the CodeSystem is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the CodeSystem content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.comment: The effective period for a CodeSystem  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the CodeSystem are or are expected to be used instead.

element.short: E.g. Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc.
element.definition: Descriptions related to the content of the CodeSystem. Topics provide a high-level categorization as well as keywords for the CodeSystem that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.comment: This element provides topical categorization and keywords for the CodeSystem, as opposed to the more structured context-of-use information provided in the useContext element
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the CodeSystem so that it can be found by topical and keyword searches.

element.short: Who authored the CodeSystem
element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the CodeSystem.

element.short: Who edited the CodeSystem
element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the CodeSystem.

element.short: Who reviewed the CodeSystem
element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the CodeSystem.

element.short: Who endorsed the CodeSystem
element.definition: An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the CodeSystem for use in some setting.

element.short: Additional documentation, citations, etc.
element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, dependencies, bibliographic references, and predecessor and successor artifacts.
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.
element.requirements: A CodeSystem must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

element.short: If code comparison is case sensitive
element.definition: If code comparison is case sensitive when codes within this system are compared to each other.
element.comment: If this value is missing, then it is not specified whether a code system is case sensitive or not. When the rule is not known, Postel's law should be followed: produce codes with the correct case, and accept codes in any case. This element is primarily provided to support validation software.

element.short: Canonical reference to the value set with entire code system
element.definition: Canonical reference to the value set that contains all codes in the code system independent of code status.
element.comment: The definition of the value set SHALL include all codes from this code system, independent of concept status, and only codes from this code system. It SHALL be immutable, and operations SHOULD support validation of any allowed code compositions.

element.short: grouped-by | is-a | part-of | classified-with
element.definition: The meaning of the hierarchy of concepts as represented in this resource.
element.comment: Note that other representations might have a different hierarchy or none at all, and represent the information using properties.

binding.description: The meaning of the hierarchy of concepts in a code system.

element.short: If code system defines a compositional grammar
element.definition: The code system defines a compositional (post-coordination) grammar.
element.comment: Note that the code system resource does not define what the compositional grammar is, only whether or not there is one.

element.short: If definitions are not stable
element.definition: This flag is used to signify that the code system does not commit to concept permanence across versions. If true, a version must be specified when referencing this code system.
element.comment:
Best practice is that code systems do not redefine concepts, or that if concepts are redefined, a new code system definition is created. But this is not always possible, so some code systems may be defined as 'versionNeeded'.

Most code systems occasionally refine the displays defined for concepts between versions. Contexts in which the concept display values are validated may require that the version be specified for some code systems irrespective of the value of this property.

element.short: not-present | example | fragment | complete | supplement
element.definition: The extent of the content of the code system (the concepts and codes it defines) are represented in this resource instance.

binding.description: The extent of the content of the code system (the concepts and codes it defines) are represented in a code system resource.

element.short: Canonical URL of Code System this adds designations and properties to
element.definition: The canonical URL of the code system that this code system supplement is adding designations and properties to.
element.comment: The most common use of a code system supplement is to add additional language support.

element.short: Total concepts in the code system
element.definition: The total number of concepts defined by the code system. Where the code system has a compositional grammar, the basis of this count is defined by the system steward.
element.comment: The count of concepts defined in this resource cannot be more than this value but may be less for several reasons - see the content element.

element.short: Filter that can be used in a value set
element.definition: A filter that can be used in a value set compose statement when selecting concepts using a filter.
element.comment: Note that filters defined in code systems usually require custom code on the part of any terminology engine that will make them available for use in value set filters. For this reason, they are generally only seen in high value published terminologies.

element.short: Code that identifies the filter
element.definition: The code that identifies this filter when it is used as a filter in [ValueSet](valueset.html#).compose.include.filter.

element.short: How or why the filter is used
element.definition: A description of how or why the filter is used.

element.short: = | is-a | descendent-of | is-not-a | regex | in | not-in | generalizes | child-of | descendent-leaf | exists
element.definition: A list of operators that can be used with the filter.

binding.description: The kind of operation to perform as a part of a property based filter.

element.short: What to use for the value
element.definition: A description of what the value for the filter should be.

element.short: Additional information supplied about each concept
element.definition: A property defines an additional slot through which additional information can be provided about a concept.
element.comment: Multiple occurrences of CodeSystem.concept.property may occur for a CodeSystem.property where     CodeSystem.concept.property.code is the same and CodeSystem.concept.property.value differs. For example: multiple designations for a single concept.

element.short: Identifies the property on the concepts, and when referred to in operations
element.definition: A code that is used to identify the property. The code is used internally (in CodeSystem.concept.property.code) and also externally, such as in property filters.

element.short: Formal identifier for the property
element.definition: Reference to the formal meaning of the property. One possible source of meaning is the [Concept Properties](codesystem-concept-properties.html) code system.

element.short: Why the property is defined, and/or what it conveys
element.definition: A description of the property- why it is defined, and how its value might be used.

element.short: code | Coding | string | integer | boolean | dateTime | decimal
element.definition: The type of the property value. Properties of type "code" contain a code defined by the code system (e.g. a reference to another defined concept).

binding.description: The type of a property value.

element.short: Concepts in the code system
element.definition: Concepts that are in the code system. The concept definitions are inherently hierarchical, but the definitions must be consulted to determine what the meanings of the hierarchical relationships are.
element.comment: If this is empty, it means that the code system resource does not represent the content of the code system.

element.short: Code that identifies concept
element.definition: A code - a text symbol - that uniquely identifies the concept within the code system.

element.short: Text to display to the user
element.definition: A human readable string that is the recommended default way to present this concept to a user.

element.short: Formal definition
element.definition: The formal definition of the concept. The code system resource does not make formal definitions required, because of the prevalence of legacy systems. However, they are highly recommended, as without them there is no formal meaning associated with the concept.

element.short: Additional representations for the concept
element.definition: Additional representations for the concept - other languages, aliases, specialized purposes, used for particular purposes, etc.
element.comment: Concepts have both a ```display``` and an array of ```designation```. The display is equivalent to a special designation with an implied ```designation.use``` of "primary code" and a language equal to the [Resource Language](resource.html#language).
element.requirements: Many concept definition systems support multiple representations, in multiple languages, and for multiple purposes.

constraint.human: Must have a value for concept.designation.use if concept.designation.additionalUse is present

element.short: Human language of the designation
element.definition: The language this designation is defined for.
element.comment: In the absence of a language, the resource language applies.

element.short: Details how this designation would be used
element.definition: A code that details how this designation would be used.
element.comment: If no use is provided, the designation can be assumed to be suitable for general display to a human user.

binding.description: Details of how a designation would be used.

element.short: Additional ways how this designation would be used
element.definition: Additional codes that detail how this designation would be used, if there is more than one use.
element.comment: This was added rather than increasing the cardinality of .use to 0..* in order to maintain backward compatibility.

binding.description: Details of how a designation would be used.

element.short: The text value for this designation
element.definition: The text value for this designation.

element.short: Property value for the concept
element.definition: A property value for this concept.

element.short: Reference to CodeSystem.property.code
element.definition: A code that is a reference to CodeSystem.property.code.

element.short: Value of the property for this concept
element.definition: The value of this property.

element.short: Child Concepts (is-a/contains/categorizes)
element.definition: Defines children of a concept to produce a hierarchy of concepts. The nature of the relationships is variable (is-a/contains/categorizes) - see hierarchyMeaning.
